Heart rate typically between 100 and 150 bpm
P wave morphology identical to sinus P waves (normal axis and shape)
Abrupt onset and termination of tachycardia
P waves precede each QRS complex with stable PR interval
No evidence of atrioventricular nodal or accessory pathway involvement
Sinus tachycardia:
Sinus rhythm with P waves preceding each QRS complex

Normal P wave morphology with consistent axis

ST-elevation myocardial infarction, high:

ST elevation in lead V2 (may be present)
Reciprocal ST depression in inferior leads, most prominent in lead III
T wave inversion in inferior leads
ST elevation pattern resembling the South African flag sign on 4×3 ECG display (ST elevation in I, aVL, V2 and ST depression in III)
ST-elevation myocardial infarction, infe:
ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF
Reciprocal ST depression in lead aVL
ST elevation in lead III > lead II
Reciprocal ST depression in lead I
Progressive development of Q waves in leads II, III, aVF
Hyperacute T waves in leads II, III, aVF
ST elevation in V1 (suggestive of right ventricular infarction)
ST elevation in V4R (indicative of right ventricular infarction)
ST elevation in lateral leads I, aVL, V5-V6 (suggestive of circumflex occlusion)

Absence of ST depression in lead I (supports circumflex artery occlusion)
Posterior myocardial infarction:
Horizontal ST depression in leads V1-V3
Tall, broad R waves (> 30 ms) in leads V1-V3
R/S ratio > 1 in lead V2
Upright T waves in leads V1-V3
ST elevation in posterior leads V7-V9 (≥ 0.5 mm)
Presence of Q waves in posterior leads V7-V9
Right ventricular myocardial infarction:
ST elevation in V1
ST elevation in V1 with ST depression in V2
Isoelectric ST segment in V1 with marked ST depression in V2
ST elevation in lead III greater than in lead II
ST elevation in right-sided lead V4R
Transient ST elevation in right-sided leads (typically lasting <10 hours)
Supraventricular tachycardia:
Regular narrow-complex tachycardia with heart rate between 140-280 bpm
QRS duration < 120 ms, unless aberrant conduction or accessory pathway present
P waves often not visible due to overlap with QRS complex
When visible, P waves show retrograde morphology with inversion in leads II, III, aVF
Retrograde P waves may be buried within the QRS, immediately after (pseudo-S waves in inferior leads), or before the QRS depending on AV nodal pathway involvement
Pseudo R’ wave in lead V1 or V2 (seen in slow-fast AVNRT)
Pseudo S waves in leads II, III, aVF (indicative of retrograde atrial activation)
R-P interval varies by subtype: short in slow-fast AVNRT, long in fast-slow AVNRT (>70 ms), and P wave in mid-diastole in slow-slow AVNRT
Rate-related ST segment depression may be present
QRS alternans (phasic variation in QRS amplitude) may be observed
Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy:
ST elevation in multiple leads, often in anterior and lateral leads
T wave inversion in multiple leads, typically evolving after initial ST elevation
QT interval prolongation
Diffuse T wave inversions involving multiple territories
New ECG changes including ST-segment deviations or T wave abnormalities not confined to a single coronary artery distribution
Ventricular fibrillation:
Chaotic irregular deflections of varying amplitude
No identifiable P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves
Rate 150 to 500 per minute
Decreasing amplitude over time (coarse VF progressing to fine VF)
Ventricular flutter:
Continuous sine wave pattern on ECG
No identifiable P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves
Rate usually > 200 beats per minute
Ventricular premature beats:
Broad QRS complex ≥ 120 ms with abnormal morphology
Premature QRS complex occurring earlier than expected in the cardiac cycle
Discordant ST segment and T wave changes relative to the main QRS vector
Full compensatory pause following the premature beat
Absence of preceding P wave before the premature QRS
Unifocal or multifocal QRS morphologies indicating single or multiple ectopic foci
Left bundle branch block pattern (dominant S wave in V1) suggesting right ventricular origin
Right bundle branch block pattern (dominant R wave in V1) suggesting left ventricular origin
Repetitive patterns such as bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy, couplets, or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT)
Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia:
Regular, broad complex tachycardia
QRS duration > 160 ms
Uniform QRS complexes within each lead (monomorphic morphology)
Absence of typical right bundle branch block (RBBB) or left bundle branch block (LBBB) morphology
Extreme axis deviation (northwest axis: between -90° and -180°)
AV dissociation (P waves and QRS complexes with independent rates)
Capture beats: narrow QRS complexes of normal duration occurring intermittently
Fusion beats: hybrid QRS complexes with intermediate morphology

Negative concordance in precordial leads (all V1–V6 show predominantly negative QRS complexes, i.e., QS complexes)

RSR’ complex in V1 with taller left rabbit ear (second R’ peak taller than first)

Absence of typical right bundle branch block (RBBB) or left bundle branch block (LBBB) morphology
Extreme axis deviation (northwest axis: between -90° and -180°)

Negative concordance in precordial leads (all V1–V6 leads show predominantly negative QS complexes)

Wellens Syndrome:
Biphasic T waves in leads V2-V3 (initial positivity followed by terminal negativity)
Deeply and symmetrically inverted T waves in leads V2-V3

Isoelectric or minimally elevated ST segment (< 1 mm) in precordial leads
Absence of precordial Q waves
Preserved R wave progression in the precordial leads
ECG pattern present during pain-free state
Pseudonormalization of T waves (transition from inverted/biphasic to upright T waves) during recurrent ischemia
Apical Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy:
Giant T-wave inversion in the precordial leads
